section.title: Don't Memorize These Formulas

li.p: Interpret the meaning of integer exponents.
Explain the derivation of the product and power rules for exponents.
Correctly execute calculations involving the product and power rules for exponents.

section.p: In an earlier section, we had worked with monomial and polynomial expressions that involved exponents. We implicitly assumed that you were familiar with the notation. We're going to formally define exponents here for the sake of completeness.

aside.p: The positive integers are the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and so forth.

statement.p:
A positive integer exponent represents repeated multiplication. The expression a^n represents the quantity a multiplied by itself n times. In other words,
a^n = \underbrace{a \cdot a \cdots a}_{\text{$n$ times}}.

section.p:
This definition allows us to write out exponent expressions "the long way" by explicitly writing out the terms in the product:
\begin{aligned} x^1 \amp = x \\ x^2 \amp = x \cdot x \\ x^3 \amp = x \cdot x \cdot x \\ \amp \vdots \end{aligned}

activity.title: The Product Rule for Exponents

aside.p: "But the equal signs aren't lined up!"
Relax. It's not a rule. It's just an organizational tool. Readability comes first.
Being able to explain your ideas in sentences helps you to understand your ideas more deeply.

activity.p: Based on the pattern observed above, what would you say x^m \cdot x^n should be equal to? Write out an explanation in both words and an equation (similar to the ones above) that explains why the pattern exists.

solution.p: Since x^m means to multiply x by itself m times, and x^n means to multiply x by itself n times, if you do the first then the second, you've multiplied x by itself m + n times in total.

activity.title: The Power Rule for Exponents
activity.p: There is a second consequence of the definition of exponents that can also been seen through some examples:

p.me: \begin{aligned} \left( x^2 \right)^3 = \underbrace{\underbrace{(x \cdot x)}_{\text{2 times}} \cdot \underbrace{(x \cdot x)}_{\text{2 times}} \cdot \underbrace{(x \cdot x)}_{\text{2 times}}}_{\text{3 groups of 2 times}} = x^6 \end{aligned}

activity.p: Based on the pattern observed above, what would you say \left( x^m \right)^n should be equal to? Write out an explanation in both words and an equation (similar to the ones above) that explains why the pattern exists.

solution.p: The product of x multiplied by itself n times is multiplied by itself m times, giving you m groups of x multiplied by itself n times, for a total of mn times that x has been multiplied by itself.

section.p: These two results are important enough that they have names.

aside.p: These may be "rules" but they are not arbitrary. If you ever get confused about whether to add or multiply the exponents, just think about the explanations you just wrote out.
Math is all about finding patterns. When we guess at something, it should be a guess based on a pattern, and not just a random guess.

section.p: The condition for this definition is worthy of a closer look. The challenge that arises is that the pattern that we had fails when x = 0. The reason is that we cannot divide by zero, so inverting the multiplication and turning it into division simply fails.

aside.p: It's interesting to think about why division by zero is not allowed. It's related to the actual concept of what it means to divide two numbers, but we'll talk more about that one later.

section.p: There are two other formulas that we can get by combining these properties.

aside.p: We will see where these formulas come from in the worksheets.

statement.p:
When x \neq 0 and n is any integer:
\left( \frac{1}{x} \right)^{-n} = x^n
\frac{1}{x^{-n}} = x^n

activity.title: Negative Exponents

aside.p: When we cancel terms in a fraction, they reduce to a 1, so this is \frac{1 \cdot x^2}{1}.

activity.title: Properties of Exponents with Negative Exponents
activity.p: The power rule for exponents also works when the exponents are zero or negative. You have all the tools you need to demonstrate this for yourself.
Calculate \left( x^{-2} \right)^3 using a presentation that shows all of the individual steps. Then verify that the power rule gives the same result.
